title: Polaroid
html:
Aug. 6 1960 Karnataka Regional Engineering College (KREC) was started with three undergraduate programs (Civil, Mechanical, Electrical) under affiliation to University of Mysore.

I have a Dream

As a young nation grew, its builders dared to dream. A distant vision, a wistful ambition; quality technical education for the masses. Carried forward on the shoulders of giants, 250 adventurous youngsters came, willing to be the foundation on which the dream could grow. Garlanded pandals and wooden chairs, dignitary visits and construction sites; they all make for gold-framed memories now, relics of an era where service came before self. We salute the pioneers who made all this possible.


A fledgling campus was brought to life by the vivacious youngsters, smiling their way through even when all was not smooth sailing. Unencumbered by the compulsory blazers and the scorching sun, their mirth and carefree laughter rings clear to this day. Musical performances or dinner-table jokes, these batches enjoyed every moment of the KREC experience.

A true smile, sunshine in the house



Keep the engines running

The dream of technical excellence was backed by well-planned, concerted efforts and setups. The engines, lathes, workshops of those days still stand tall, glowing tribute to the early visionaries. Triple placements may well have been far off, but the march was on, firm and strong. Truly, things take off only when you keep the engines running.

On court

Even at a time when hostels where years away from being the rooms we now know, batches were forever energetic and enthusiastic, giving their all both in the classroom and the sports field. Shot put, tug-of-war and kabaddi – they all drew crowds, cheering the fierce competitions with passion intense. Basketball was played with footballs on mud, but with spirit that would put many to shame today. Students raced ahead on the track, little knowing how it would become a metaphor for KRECians to come.

All the world’s a stage

Greasepaint would be slapped on vigorously, Elvis-sideburns grown. Crowds would gather in front of the biggest stage of the time, the one next to the SS, looking forward to an evening of entertainment and merrymaking. Cloth screens would transform the electrical machines lab to a theatre of dreams, with elaborate dramas staged for everybody’s entertainment, language no bar. Musical performances of the time too had diverse appeal; harmonium and tabla maestros often sharing the stage with hairbands and guitars.

The global experience

A faculty exchange program saw six Canadian professors on campus, very much becoming a part of campus life, of academics and the busting social interactions alike. Clearly, the global experience that was aimed at had very, very early beginnings.

A hundred more stories in sepia…
